title: Line, Area and Column charts
description: The FusionCharts Suite XT standard charts are simple charts used to plot single-series data.

title: Column 2D Chart
description: Column and bar charts represent data with rectangular horizontal or vertical bars. The height of the bars is proportional to the values they represent. In case of a column chart, the numeric values are plotted along the y-axis, and the data labels are plotted along the x-axis. Whereas in bar charts, the numeric values are plotted along the x-axis, and the data labels are plotted along the y-axis. Column and bar charts are best fitted when you want to compare values.

title: Column 3D Chart
description: To render a column chart in 3D, change the value of the type attribute from column2D to column3D. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Bar 2D Chart
description: Now, let's create a bar 2D chart. In the chart below, we have shown five stores in a supermarket that have highest sales. The sales figures are plotted along the x-axis, and the store names are plotted along the y-axis.

title: Bar 3D Chart
description: To render a bar chart in 3D, change the value of the type attribute from bar2D to bar3D. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Line Chart
description: Line charts are commonly used to showcase the trend in data over time whereas area charts are used to display quantitative data. Information in a line or area chart is plotted on the x- and y-axis; data values are plotted using data points that are connected using line segments.

title: Area Chart
description: An area chart is similar to the line chart, with the difference that the area marked by the anchors and line segments is filled.

title: Plot Trend Elements
description: The trend elements on a chart include trend-lines and trend-zones.

title: Plot Vertical Line Elements
description: Vertical (or horizontal in case of bar charts) separator lines are elements that can differentiate between data blocks in a chart. They can be placed between any two data points or can be aligned to specific data points.

title: Change Chart Type
description: FusionCharts Suite XT allows you to change the chart type dynamically through its advanced API. You can change chart type by calling the chartType() method on any FusionCharts' instance and provide the chart name as an argument.

title: Data Skipping
description: Visualization plays a crucial role in data science, helping data scientists to make sense of the underlying patterns within data, even before any other computation begins. With v3.12.0, FusionCharts has evolved to consume a large amount of data in standard charts.

title: Pie and Doughnut Charts
description: Pie and Donut Charts are great tools for visualizing Part-to-whole relationships in a dataset. This handy guide teaches all about making pie and doughnut charts with custom attributes like labels, lines, radius, angles and much more.

title: Pie 2D Chart
description: Let's create our first pie 2D chart which will showcase the split in revenue by product categories for one year.

title: Pie 3D Chart
description: To render a pie chart in 3D, change the value of the type attribute from pie2D to pie3D. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Doughnut 2D Chart
description: As we know, a doughnut chart is similar to a pie chart. The only difference is that a doughnut chart has a blank center - as the name suggests, it looks like a doughnut.

title: Doughnut 3D Chart
description: To render a doughnut chart in 3D, change the value of the type attribute from doughnut2D to doughnut3D. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Configure the Animation Direction
description: By default, when a pie/doughnut chart is loaded for the first time or refreshed, the rendering animation is in the anti-clockwise direction. However, FusionCharts includes the animateClockwise attribute that lets you animate the chart in the clockwise direction. Set the animateClockwise attribute to 1 to animate the chart in the clockwise direction.

title: Show Percent Values and Actual Values
description: By default, for a pie chart, the actual data values are shown on the chart as well as in the tool-tips. However, you can choose to show percent values on the chart while retaining the actual values in tool-tips.

title: Customize the Center Label for a Doughnut Chart
description: For a doughnut chart, you can configure the default text that will be rendered on the center label. You can also configure the text that will be rendered on the center label when the mouse pointer is hovered over one of the doughnut slices.

title: Enable Single-Slice Slicing
description: By default, the pie and doughnut charts allow you to slice out multiple pie/doughnut slices at one time. You can, however, opt to enable slicing-out only one slice at a time.

title: Disable Smart Labels and Lines
description: By default, pie and doughnut charts are rendered with smart labels and lines - smart labels are data labels connected to their corresponding pie slices using line segments called smart lines. Smart labels manage overlapping of labels even when a large number of labels are placed in the close vicinity. You can, however, choose to disable these smart labels.

title: Customize Smart Lines
description: Apart from enabling and disabling the smart lines, you can also set the cosmetic properties of smart lines. To customize the smart lines, follow the steps given below:

title: Configuring the Label Distance and Clearance
description: Now, you already know how to customize the labels and the label lines in a chart. Here let's discuss how to configure the label distance of a chart.

title: Skip Overlap Labels
description: When there are too many labels in the pie/doughnut chart (which is difficult to adjust even if you are using smart labels), the labels may overlap. In this case, you have the option to skip the overlapping labels. The labels of the least significant pies will be removed. To skip the overlapping of labels set the skipOverlapLabels attribute to 1.

title: Customize Pie Radius
description: By default, for pie/doughnut charts, the chart automatically calculates the best fit pie radius based on the data provided. However, you can choose to explicitly set the outer radius of the pie chart. Specify the outer radius of the pie/doughnut chart using pieRadius attribute.

title: Set the Starting Angle
description: By default, pie/doughnut charts start plotting from the 0Â° angle. The chart allows you to explicitly set the starting angle. Specify the startingAngle attribute set the starting angle for the pie/doughnut chart. The first pie slice will start plotting from the angle measure specified in this attribute.

title: Slice a Pie/Doughnut
description: When a pie/doughnut chart first renders, by default, all slices are sliced-in. However, to highlight a slice, you may want to render it sliced-out when the chart first loads. isSliced attribute can be used to specify the pie chart will be rendered with one slice sliced-out. Set this attribute to 1 for a pie slice to render a slice sliced-out. This attribute belongs to the data object.

title: Configure the Slicing Distance
description: When a pie/doughnut slice is sliced-out, you can configure the distance between the center and the sliced-out slices. Set the distance (in pixels) between the center of the chart and the sliced out slices using slicingDistance attribute.

title: Configure the Bevel Effect
description: For pie/doughnut charts, you can configure the bevel effect to render the chart with 3D effects. Set the use3DLighting attribute to 1 to specify whether advanced gradients and shadow effects will be used to create better looking charts.

title: Multi-series Charts
description: FusionCharts Suite XT includes multi-series charts that allow to plot data for multiple datasets. For example, you can plot the revenue collected each month for the last two years using a multi-series chart.

title: Multi-series Column 2D Chart
description: In this sample, let's create a multi-series column 2D chart showcasing the comparison between quarterly revenue earned for the previous year and the current year. The columns for both datasets, one for the previous year and one for the current year, have been rendered using different colors. This makes it easy to interpret and compare the data.

title: Multi-series Column 3D Chart
description: To render a multi-series column chart in 3D, change the value of the type attribute from msColumn2D to msColumn3D. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Multi-series Bar 2D Chart
description: Let's move ahead to create a multi-series bar chart in 2D which will show sales as per two major categories in different stores for last month.

title: Multi-series Bar 3D Chart
description: To render a multi-series bar chart in 3D, change the value of the type attribute from msBar2D to msBar3D. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Multi-series Line Chart
description: Now, let's create a multi-series line chart which will show the comparison between the number of visitors in malls in a week. The line segments for both datasets, one for the last week and one for the current week, have been rendered using different colors. This makes it easy to interpret and compare the data.

title: Multi-series Area Chart
description: To render a multi-series area chart the same use case as above, set the type to msarea.

title: Overlapped Column and Bar Charts
description: In overlapped charts, the two data series overlap. The width of the plot for the data series differs which makes the chart easy to compare.

title: Overlapped Column 2D Chart
description: In this sample let's create an Overlapped Column 2D chart comparing the "Healthcare Expenditure per capita" between public and private sectors.

title: Overlapped Bar 2D Chart
description: To render an overlapped bar 2D chart, change the value of type attribute from overlappedColumn2D to overlappedBar2D. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Combination Charts
description: Combination charts allow you to plot multiple datasets on the same chart. But an added advantage with using combination charts is that you can also plot multiple chart types on the same chart.

title: 2D Single Y-axis Combination Chart
description: Let's create our first combination chart to showcase the comparison of actual revenue, projected revenue and the profit earned for each month of the last year. All three metrics have been plotted using different chart types - the actual revenue earned is plotted using a column chart, the projected revenue is plotted using a line chart, and the profit earned is plotted using an area chart.

title: 3D Single Y-axis Combination Chart
description: To render a single y-axis combination chart in 3D, change the value of the type attribute from mscombi2d to mscombi3d. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: 2D Dual Y-axis Combination Chart
description: Now, let's create a dual y-axis combination chart in 2D. For this, change the value of the type attribute from mscombi2d to mscombidy2d.

title: Column 3D + Line Single Y-axis Chart
description: Now, let's create a column and line multi-series chart in 3D. For this, set the value of the type attribute to mscolumnline3d.

title: Column 3D + Line Dual Y-axis Chart
description: To render a column 3D and line multi-series chart with dual y-axis, change the value of the type attribute from mscolumnline3d to mscolumn3dlinedy.

title: Stacked Column 2D Line Single Y-axis Chart
description: Now, let's create a combination of stacked column and a line chart in 2D. For this, set the value of type attribute to stackedcolumn2dline.

title: Stacked Column 3D Line Single Y-axis Chart
description: To render the stacked column 3D and line chart with single y-axis, change the value of the type attribute from stackedcolumn2dline to stackedcolumn3dline. Rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Stacked Column 3D Line Dual Y-axis Chart
description: To render the stacked column 3D and line chart with dual y-axis, change the value of the type attribute from stackedcolumn3dline to stackedcolumn3dlinedy. Rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Multi Series Stacked Column 2D + Line Dual Y-axis Chart
description: To render the multi-series stacked column + line dual y-axis chart in 2D, set the value of type attribute to msstackedcolumn2dlinedy.

title: Plot Trend Elements
description: For a dual y-axis chart, you can plot trend-lines for both, the primary y-axis and the secondary y-axis. The following sample will showcase the average revenue trend-line which will be plotted against the primary y-axis that shows the amount in USD. The average profit percent trend-line will be plotted against the secondary y-axis that shows the profit percent.

title: Placing the Secondary Axis on the Left
description: You can choose to swap positions of the primary and secondary axes using a single attribute i.e., primaryAxisOnLeft. Set this attribute to 1, to render the primary axis on the left and the secondary axis on right.

title: Stacked Charts
description: In stacked chart plot datasets are on top of each other. They help in displaying the cumlative magnitude of two or more data series.

title: Stacked column 2D Chart
description: As an example, we will create a stacked column 2D chart to plot the revenue split for each quarter of the current year by product category - food products and non-food products. The data plots for each category are rendered using two distinct colors to help interpretation. The data plots for non-food products are stacked above the data plots for food products, instead of alongside as in multi-series charts.

title: Stacked Column 3D Chart
description: To render a stacked column chart in 3D, change the value of the type attribute from stackedcolumn2d to stackedcolumn3d. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Stacked Area 2D Chart
description: To render a stacked area chart in 2D, change the value of the type attribute from stackedcolumn3d to stackedarea2d. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Stacked Bar 2D Chart
description: To render a stacked bar chart in 2D, change the value of the type attribute from stackedarea2d to stackedbar2d. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Stacked Bar 3D Chart
description: To render a stacked bar chart in 3D, change the value of the type attribute from stackedbar2d to stackedbar3d. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Display the Cumulative Sum
description: You can opt to show the sum of all stacked data plots in a column above that column. To show the sum of all stacked data plots, set the showSum attribute to 1.

title: Create 100% Stacked Charts
description: You can use stacked charts to show the percentage distribution for individual items of a dataset. These stacked charts are called 100% Stacked Charts. The y-axis, instead of representing the actual data values, represents the percentage values.

title: Show Percent Values in Tool-Tips
description: By default, actual data values are rendered in tool-tips. Set the showPercentInToolTip to 1 to show the percentage values in tool-tips.

title: Scroll Chart
description: Charts with scrolls allows you to plot large quantities of data. They are also used to avoid cluttering of plots.

title: Scroll Column 2D Chart
description: Let's create a scroll column 2D chart to plot the sales trends for FY 2012 - FY 2013.

title: Scroll Line 2D Chart
description: Now, let's create a scroll line 2D chart. To render a scroll line chart in 2D, change the value of the type attribute from scrollColumn2d to scrollline2d. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Scroll Area 2D Chart
description: Let's create the scroll area 2D chart. To render a scroll area chart in 2D, change the value of the type attribute from scrollline2d to scrollarea2d. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Scroll Stacked Column 2D Chart
description: Stacked charts are the multi-series charts with the plot datasets on top of each other. Now, let's create a scroll stacked column 2D chart. The example will plot the sales comparison w.r.t. the products and services for FY 2017-FY 2018.

title: Scroll Combination 2D Chart
description: Now, we will create a scroll combination 2D chart to plot the revenue and the profit earned, in dollars, and the profit for FY 2017-FY 2018.

title: Scroll Combination 2D Dual Y-axis Chart
description: To create a scroll combination 2D chart with a dual y-axis, change the value of the type attribute to scrollcombidy2d. Here we will plot the revenue and the profit earned, in dollars, and the profit percent for FY 2017-FY 2018.

title: Configure the Number of Visible Data Plots
description: Scroll charts are generally used to avoid cluttering. With that in FusionCharts, you can also configure the number of data plots that will be visible in the scroll pane when the chart is first loaded. To configure this specify the number of visible plots using the numVisiblePlot attribute.

title: Render a Scroll Bar with Gradient Effect
description: By default, a scroll chart has a flat scroll bar. You can opt to render a gradient scroll to visually enhance your chart. To render the scroll in gradient set the flatScrollBars attribute to 0.

title: Customizing the Scroll Bar
description: The scroll bar of the scroll chart can be customized using the cosmetic properties. To the customize the scroll bar, follow the steps below:

title: Bubble and Scatter Charts
description: Bubble and Scatter are used for plotting data that is defined in terms of two numeric parameters.

title: Scatter Chart
description: Scatter charts are used for plotting data that is defined in terms of two numeric parameters. Scatter charts are multi-series charts, but their data format is slightly different from that of conventional multi-series charts.

title: Bubble Charts
description: Bubble charts are used for plotting data that is defined in terms of three numeric parameters. The third numeric parameter is indicated by the diameter of the bubble. The JSON/XML format of a bubble chart is slightly different from that of a scatter chart, and this is because the bubble chart plots an additional numeric parameter.

title: Display Value Labels on Bubbles
description: By default, data labels are not rendered on the bubbles in a bubble chart. To show individual labels for the bubbles in the chart, set the showValues attribute to 1.

title: Segment the x-axis into Categorical Zones
description: The x-axis of the bubble/scatter chart can be segmented into categorical zones using vertical trend lines. To set the categorical zones follow the steps given below:

title: Configure X-axis Labels
description: You can configure the display mode of the x-axis labels for bubble and scatter charts. You can either choose to make the chart automatically generate the x-axis labels along with vertical divisional lines or you can explicitly define each x-axis label. Additionally, you can also opt to mix these two modes.

title: Configure the x-axis Vertical Divisional Lines
description: X-axis vertical divisional lines are vertical lines running through the canvas in the chart. These lines are important in case of bubble charts as they divide the canvas into different sections. You can configure these lines as per your requirement.

title: Connect Scatter Plots by a Line
description: In scatter charts, you can connect the scatter plots by a line. Set the drawLine attribute to 1, which will connect the data points using a line. The default value for this attribute is 0. This attribute belongs to the dataset object.

title: Draw Regression Lines
description: In scatter and bubble charts, each data point has two distinct numeric values: the x value for the x-axis and the y value for the y-axis.

title: Draw Quadrants
description: Dividing the canvas of a bubble/scatter chart into quadrants makes the analysis of the chart easier. Set the value of drawQuadrant attribute to 1 to draw quadrants for the chart. The default value of this attribute is 0.

title: Display Quadrant Labels
description: In XY charts you can also set the label for all individual quadrants. To add labels the charts, follow the points given below:

title: Customize Quadrant Labels
description: The quadrant labels shown in the above chart can be customized according to the use case. Each cosmetic property can be customized by setting the attribute for it. You can customize the font, font color, the transparency and the size of the font. The cosmetics of the label border and the background can also be customized if required.

title: Customize Quadrant Lines
description: Customize the quadrant lines in the bubble chart using the list of attributes given below:

title: Pareto Chart
description: In this section of Pareto chart you will be introduced to the basics of the Pareto chart and how you can create a simple one.

title: Pareto 2D
description: In this example, let's create a pareto 2D chart showcasing the late arrivals of the employee by their respective reported cause. The primary y-axis shows the number of occurrences of the employee per month whereas the secondary y-axis shows the cumulative percentage.

title: Pareto 3D
description: To render a pareto chart in 3D, change the value of the type attribute from pareto2D to pareto3D. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Display Values for the Line Series
description: By default, the auto-generated percentage values for the line chart are not rendered. To specify the percentage data values for the line chart, set the showLineValues attribute to 1.

title: Customize the Line Dataset
description: In a pareto chart, you can customize the cosmetic of the line rendered. Given below are the cosmetic which can be applied to customize the line dataset.

title: Hide Secondary Axis Values
description: Depending on the use case, hide the secondary y-axis of the pareto chart by following the steps given below:

title: Marimekko Chart
description: Marimekko charts are stacked column charts with columns of variable width. They are primarily used for marketing analysis.

title: Create a Marimekko Chart
description: Let's create a simple Marimekko chart that shows the top 3 Electronic Brands (Bose, Dell, and Apple) in the top 3 revenue earning states (California, Washington, and Nevada).

title: Display Actual Data Values
description: The stacked columns in a Marimekko chart can be rendered:

title: Hide the Total value of Market Segments
description: By default, the total value of a market segment for a competitor is rendered at the top of each column.

title: Percentage Market Share Values
description: By default, labels are rendered between the columns of a Marimekko chart, along the x-axis, to show the percentage market value share of the competitors. These labels can be shown/hidden, depending on what the user requirement is. Set the showXAxisPercentValues attribute to 0 to hide the percent values along the x-axis. The default value of this attribute is 1.

title: Legend Interactivity
description: The Marimekko chart includes support for an interactive legend starting FusionCharts Suite XT v3.11.0. The interactive legend implementation for the Marimekko chart not only lets you show/hide the data plots but also manages the space vacated when data plots are hidden. Consequently, the percentage labels are also updated to reflect the current state of the chart.

title: Treemap
description: Treemapping is a visual representation of an information tree created using the tree data structure displayed as 2D nested rectangles,representing the nodes

title: Applications of a treemap
description: Use a treemap to display hierarchical information presented using a tree structure. You can, for instance, use a treemap to show the folder structure of a system. You can also use it to study patterns and occurrences in a large dataset since the color, and the size dimensions are correlated.

title: Visualization of a treemap
description: In the image given below, you can see how an information tree is translated to the treemap:

title: How to build a good treemap
description:
Structure the data so that it has only one root element.

Represent a dimension, a trend, or a deviation from a key value with the color of a rectangle.

Represent the innermost rectangle as the leaf node. The area of this rectangle is always proportional to the data value assigned to that leaf.

Avoid nesting nodes that are not leaves. The areas of these rectangles are less significant.

To build an ideal treemap, maintain the aspect ratio as 1.

title: Important concepts related to the treemap
description: Tiling

title: Interact with a Treemap
description: Interaction Model (as-is)

title: Create a simple treemap
description: A treemap is useful when you need to analyze hierarchical information. You can compare the 2D nested rectangles of a treemap to quickly gain insights from the data. To render a treemap chart, include fusioncharts.treemap.js in the project folder with rest of the .js files as mentioned here.

title: Render a gradient legend
description: You can have a treemap rendered with the gradient legend, which is a pane of blended colors derived from the colorRange definitions. You can have the linear scale drawn with a pair of draggable pointers. That way, each color you define for a numeric range will blend into the next color at its end point, forming a gradient strip. Each point on the gradient scale will represent a unique color and value. As such, all different values in the chart will appear in unique colors as per their positions on the gradient scale.

title: Set tiling algorithm for the treemap
description: Tiling is the process of dividing large rectangles into smaller sub-rectangles. Ideally, a treemap tiling algorithm creates rectangles with an aspect ratio that is close to 1, with ordering based on the underlying data/information tree.

description: Using FusionCharts Suite XT, you can configure the functionality of your treemap. There are various ways in which you can customize your treemap. For instance, you can:

description: Use the following attributes to customize individual data plots:

description: Use the following attributes to customize all text within the chart canvas, including all the captions and sub-captions:

description: Use the following attributes to customize only the data labels in the chart:

description: You can apply a background color different from the label font color to data labels, generating a glow effect. This is useful when the data label font color and the rectangle fill color are either same or similar, which can happen when the chart is rendered with a gradient legend.

description: Using FusionCharts Suite XT, you can configure standard interactivity for items like tooltips and gradient legend, through the treemap attributes. However, if you need to further extend chart interactivity, you can raise the following JavaScript events for this chart, and then build your custom modifications over them:

title: Heat Map Chart
description: A heat map chart is a specialized chart that uses colors to represent data values in a table. It is mostly used to plot large and complex data.

title: Basics of a heat map chart
description: You can use the heat map chart to plot data like employee attendance records, a periodic table, tracking investments in the stock market, comparing the performance of different companies, etc. You can set different colors for different levels of data. For example, if you use the heat map chart to plot employee attendance records, you can use colors like red, yellow, blue and green to indicate a bad, average, good, and excellent grade, respectively, based on percentage values. Once the chart, you will be able to easily distinguish the four grades.

title: Features of a heat map chart
description: Using a heat map chart, you can:

title: Types of heat map charts
description: Using FusionCharts Suite XT, you can build two types of heat map charts. Use the numeric heat map chart to plot numeric data, and the category based heat map chart to plot non-numeric data. These charts look as shown below:

title: Legends in heat map charts
description: As stated earlier, you can use two different types of legends with heat map charts:

description: Use the following attributes to create a simple numeric heat map chart:

title: Define the order of rows and columns
description: In the chart given above, you can see that the chart automatically decides the order of rows and columns according to the sequence in which you define them for the data object. So, the chart displays Samsung Galaxy S5 in the first row, HTC One (M8) in the second, and so on.

title: Configure colors for individual cells
description: Specify the hex code for the color that will be applied to a cell using the color attribute with the data object.

title: Create category based heat map charts
description: You can do category based mapping by defining several color categories or ranges, and set a specific color category to a cell. You don't need to map numeric values to value ranges. Instead, use a color range to map a cell with a color category.

title: Legend options
description: You can create two types of legends in heat map charts built with FusionCharts Suite XT - the icon legend and the gradient legend.

title: Create a gradient legend
description: A gradient legend is a pane of blended colors derived from the colorRange definitions and features a linear scale is drawn with two draggable pointers. Each color you define for a numeric range blends with the next color, forming a gradient strip. Each point on the gradient scale represents a unique color and value. So, all the different values in the chart appear in unique colors as per the position on the gradient scale.

title: Configure labels and tooltips
description: Using FusionCharts XT, you can configure the functional properties of labels and tooltips.

title: Handle out-of-range data
description: If data values are beyond the numeric ranges you define in the colorRange object; the chart shows blank data plots. A chart with a blank data plot rendered for out-of-range data looks like the following:

title: Map data by percentage
description: Using percentage mapping, you can display data values in percentage. Set the value of the mapByPercent attribute to 1, to enable percentage mapping for heat map charts.

title: Gantt Chart
description: The Gantt chart is a specialized chart used for displaying various timelines like project timelines, development timelines, etc.

title: Basics of the Gantt chart
description: A Gantt chart is a date/time-based chart, with which you can plot tasks visually, with their exact start and end dates/times. You can also define milestones for the project, which assert how much of the project should be completed at a given point in time. That way, you can keep track of the project progress and plan remedial actions to bring the project back on course, if there is a delay.

title: Features of the Gantt Chart
description: With a Gantt chart, you can:

title: Elements of the Gantt Chart
description: A Gantt chart consists of the following elements:

title: Categories and subcategories (dates)
description: A Gantt chart has a horizontal axis representing the total time span of the project. You can break this axis down into increments (for example, days, weeks, or months). You can also define any number of sub-categories to show dates broken into smaller units. For example, if you want to show a Gantt chart spanning two years, you can show the first sub-category as quarters, then divide these quarters into months, then weeks, and finally into days.

title: Process Names
description: Each task in a Gantt chart is represented as a process. For example, in the images shown above, we have the processes "Writing", "Signing", "Financing", etc. Whenever you build a Gantt chart, you need to specify the process names and also the tasks within each process.

title: Data Table to Show Additional Data Columns
description: If you need to provide more data pertinent to each process, you can show that data in an interactive and fully customizable data table. This data table is draggable and scrollable. Also, each cell's cosmetics can be thoroughly customized and data in each cell can be linked to external targets.

title: Task Bars
description: Task bars are the actual bars which represent the duration of each task. They run through the horizontal length of the chart and are positioned with respect to dates specified for each of them.

title: Milestones
description: Milestones are an important part of the Gantt chart as they allow you to visually depict any crucial dates on the chart. You can create your own milestones on the chart based on the date and the tasks, i.e., for a given task you can specify milestones on specific dates. You can customize all the visual properties of the milestone including shape (star or polygon), size, and colors.

title: Task Connectors
description: You can draw connectors between the task bars to indicate the process flow.

title: Trend-lines
description: You can use trend-lines to show important dates on the chart - like today, or a scheduled date, etc.

title: Legend
description: You can define your own legend and keys for the chart. This is an optional requirement but can be useful to depict what each color represents.

title: Vertical Scroll Bar
description: A vertical scroll bar appears at the right side of the Gantt view pane in Gantt chart.

title: Create a simple Gantt chart
description: The Gantt chart is a specialized chart that you can use to monitor the progress of a project. In this section, you will see how to create a simple Gantt chart.

description: Use the following attributes to define and set the visibility of the task labels:

description: Use the following attributes to show/hide task start and end dates:

description: The Social Media Optimization Gantt chart that we have been looking at so far looks like the following:

title: Customize the hover effect
description: In a Gantt chart, the hover effect is rendered as a vertical/horizontal band when you hover the mouse pointer over a category/process header. Different ways in which you can customize the hover effect for a Gantt chart include the following.

title: Disable hover effects
description: Use the following attributes to disable the hover effect:

title: Configure task bars
description: You can customize the way task bars render on the chart in the following ways:

title: Configure date formats
description: Using FusionCharts Suite XT, you can input the date in one format and output it using a custom format.

title: Add scroll to chart
description: The Gantt chart supports scrolling for both the data table and the Gantt view pane.

title: Add Multiple Tasks to a Process
description: You may come across scenarios, where a process comprises multiple tasks. A Gantt chart allows you to create multiple tasks for processes by mapping tasks and processes using IDs.

title: Create Time-based Charts
description: Using FusionCharts Suite XT, you can create date-based and time-based charts, as well as charts that plot both date and time.

title: Create Date+Time-based Charts
description: As an example here, let's plot a time-based Gantt chart to show the development division's work schedule over two days.

title: Add milestones to a chart
description: You can use milestones on a Gantt chart, to visually depict crucial dates. You can create your own milestones on the chart based on dates and tasks, and customize all of their visual properties, including the shapes (star or polygon), sizes, and colors. You can also add tool text for milestones. Use the following attributes to add milestones to a Gantt chart:

title: Connect Tasks on Chart
description: You can draw connectors between any two tasks on the chart to show the process flow.

title: Add Trend-lines
description: You can use trend-lines and trend-zones to represent a target value and a target range, respectively. You can add them to your Gantt chart to mark an event for a particular data. For example, you can add a trend-line to indicate "Testing Start" or a trend-zone to show the Christmas vacation period.

title: Events in Gantt chart
description: You can configure the following events for Gantt charts:

title: Zoom Line Chart
description: The FusionCharts Suite XT zoom line chart is a special type of multi-series line chart that allows analysis of data at macroscopic and microscopic levels.

title: Create a Zoomline Chart
description: As an example, we will create a zoom line chart that plots the number of unique website visits to the harrysfoodmart.com and the harrysfashion.com websites for every day of the last year.

title: Create a Zoom-line Dual Y-axis Chart
description: The FusionCharts Suite XT zoom-line dual y-axis chart, like the zoom-line chart, is used to analyze data at macroscopic and microscopic levels. With the dual y-axis, this chart can be used to plot data that belongs to datasets having different numeric units on the same chartâan advantage over using the conventional zoom-line chart.

title: Limit the Number of Data Labels
description: By default, the zoom line chart displays as many data labels as can be accommodated without causing a clutter.

title: Set the Distance between the Data Plots
description: In zoom line chart, set the distance (in pixels) between consecutive data plots using the pixelsPerPoint attribute. A greater number of pixels will result in a higher quality display.

title: Set the Criteria for Anchor Display
description: In order to reduce clutter, you can make anchors visible only when the distance between consecutive data points reaches a certain minimum value. For instance, you can instruct the chart to show anchors only when consecutive data points are 25 pixels apart.

title: Pre-select the Number of Visible Data Plots
description: By default, the zoom line chart displays all the data plots on a single screen. However, it is possible to pre-select the maximum number of data plots that will be visible on a single screen at the time of rendering.

title: Customize the Appearance of a Zoom-line Chart
description: FusionCharts Suite XT includes several options for customizing the appearance of a zoom line chart. The appearance of chart elements such as the scroll bar and toolbar can be configured.

title: Customize the Peak Data Limits
description: Zoomline chart shows large number of datasets. For instance, you can use it to plot daily revenue of two or more departments for the last 10 years.

title: Drag-able Charts
description: Drag-able Charts are used to visually manipulate the data on a chart in Real-Time. Learn how to make interactive drag charts with customized axis limits, divisional lines, data retrieval and much more.

title: Drag-able Column 2D Chart
description: Let's create our first drag-able column 2D chart showcasing the actual and estimated inventory status for the top five food items at Bakersfield Central.

title: Drag-able Line 2D Chart
description: To render a drag-able line 2D chart, change the value of the type attribute from dragcolumn2d to dragline.

title: Drag-able Area 2D Chart
description: To render a drag-able area 2D chart, change the value of the type attribute from dragline to dragarea. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Change Axis Limits
description: The chart, by default, calculates the y-axis upper and lower limits based on the data provided to it. To let the column assume a value not covered within this axis range, increase or decrease the limits using the menu button at the top-right of the chart.

title: Manage Chart Limits using JavaScript API
description: With FusionCharts Suite XT, you can set and retrieve the charts' upper and lower limits using JavaScript APIs. Some of the methods to set and retrieve the charts' limits are given below:

title: Snap to the Nearest Divisional Lines
description: Limit the dragging of data plots with respect to the divisional lines on the chart i.e. you can configure a data plot to snap to the nearest divisional line if it falls within a specified distance of the divisional line.

title: Retrieve a Dataset
description: A drag-able column 2D chart can be configured to retrieve JSON data and render it in an alert window. getJSONData function needs to be called on an existing chart. It fetches data that has been set on the chart in the JSON format. Calling this function on a chart with no data set will return an empty { } object.

title: Retrieve Data using getDataWithID() Function
description: The getDataWithID() function returns a three-dimensional array that contains the data and the dataset IDs. Once the reference for the chart is obtained, this function can be invoked to retrieve data.

title: Retrieve Data using getData() Function
description: The getData() function is similar to the getDataWithID() function except that it returns just the updated value of the data on the chart and not its ID.

title: Select-scatter Chart
description: The select-scatter chart is a special type of chart that allows users to visually select a subset of data from the given data points.

title: Select Set of Points
description: To select a set of points, you can drag and draw a rectangle over the chart. All the points within this rectangle are now selected points. Once the rectangle has been drawn, you can resize it to adjust more points. The resize handlers let you do so.

title: Get Selected Data
description: After you select a subset of data points in a select-scatter chart and click Submit, the selected data is sent to a server-side script, or a JavaScript function, for further processing. Here you will see how the updated data is read using the JavaScript functions present on the same page.

title: Read JSON data from the Chart
description: The chart also provides a method to read the selected data in the JSON/XML format. This method is named as the getJSONData() and can be invoked as under:

title: Draw Regression Lines
description: A regression line, rendered as a straight line, is used to show the trend of y values for the x values or the trend of x values for the y values. A regression line, therefore, can be used to derive a particular trend from the scattered data points in the chart canvas and predict values accordingly. For example, regression lines can be used to find trends and predict future sales, stock prices, currency exchange rates, productivity gains resulting from a training program, and so on.

title: Zoom Scatter Chart
description: The  zoom-scatter chart is primarily used to find correlations between datasets. Correlations in the chart can be determined by visual patterns in the data.

title: Create a Zoom Scatter chart
description: Let's create a chart which compares the admission rate (in percent) with the average annual returns on the degree (in percent) for five majors and over a period of 20 years.

title: The Zoom-scatter Chart Toolbar
description: The zoom-scatter chart toolbar is an important interaction mode for the users of this chart. The toolbar, shown in the image below, is located in the top-right corner of the chart.

title: Draw Regression Lines
description: A regression line, rendered as a straight line, is used to show the trend of y values for the x values or the trend of x values for the y values. A regression line, therefore, can be used to derive a particular trend from the scattered data points in the chart canvas and predict values accordingly. For example, regression lines can be used to find trends and predict future sales, stock prices, currency exchange rates, productivity gains resulting from a training program, and so on.

title: Radar Chart
description: A radar chart is a visual interpretation of data bearing multiple dimensions, the radial grid like structure,the chart displays different categories values

title: Funnel Chart
description: A funnel chart is used to plot streamlined data. For example, it can be used to plot the sales data for a sales pipeline analysis.

title: Salient Features
description: Features of a funnel chart that you may find useful:

title: Create a Funnel Chart
description: We will create a funnel chart that shows the purchase-conversion analysis, using the data provided in the table below. It will filter out data to finally show how many people who visited the website actually purchased something.

title: Draw a 2D funnel chart with customized borders
description: By default, a funnel chart renders as a 3D chart with a context menu, which you can use to switch between the 2D and the 3D modes of display. However, you can configure a funnel chart to be rendered in the 2D mode when it first loads, without using the context menu. You can also customize the border properties of a funnel chart for improved visual representation.

title: Show labels at the center of the chart
description: Set the value of the showLabelsAtCenter attribute to 1, to specify whether the data labels should be shown in the center of the data plots.

title: Show Labels in the Legend
description: You can show the labels in the legend box, instead of showing them with the data plots. To do this, show the legend box and hide the labels for the data plots. The following attributes are used:

title: Configure the position of the legend box
description: By default, the legend box is placed at the bottom of the funnel chart. You can, however, change the position of the legend box and shift it to the right.

title: Draw Filled Funnel Slices (in 3D Mode)
description: In a 3D funnel chart, the slices are rendered as hollow by default. You can, however, render them as filled. Set the isHollow attribute to 1, to render filled funnel slices.

title: Draw all slices with the same slant angle
description: By default, whenever you plot streamlined data, the chart uses variable funnel slice width - the slant angle - to visually depict the filtering process. However, you can also use the same slant angle for all funnel slices. Set the useSameSlantAngle attribute to 1, to use the same slant angle for all slices.

title: Show values as percentage of the previous value
description: When showing values in percentage for each slice, you can ask the chart to calculate the percentage value of the slice with respect to the previous slice (instead of the first slice). To do so, use the attributes given below:

title: Slice Out Individual Funnel Slices
description: At times, you may want to highlight important data so that it can be easily noticed. In a funnel chart, you can slice out the funnel slice that represents any such data. Set the isSliced attribute to 1 to slice out a particular data slice. Note that you can either use this attribute as part of the chart object (in which case it will apply to all slices), or the data object (in which case it will only apply to the slice(s) for which you define it).

title: Configure Hover Effects
description: Use the following attributes to configure the hover effect:

title: Pyramid Chart
description: Pyramid charts are used for comparison of data. This section indroduces some basics of pyramid chart with some of its silent features

title: Salient features
description:
Click on Interactive pyramid slices to separate them from the main pyramid.

Right click on the chart and select View 2D to seamlessly convert 3D pyramid to 2D pyramid.

Render the pyramid in 2D mode with more control over border and fill properties.

Show values as actual values or in percentage.

Use smart labels to avoid overlapping of pyramid labels.

Place labels on the side or in the center of the chart.

Use custom tool text for each pyramid slice.

Link each pyramid slice to a valid target, such as a web page, a Javascript function, or even a drill down chart, if you wish.

title: Create a simple pyramid chart
description: Build the Global Wealth Pyramid (Credit Suisse 2013) chart using the data given below, to see how the world's wealth was distributed during that year:

title: Draw a 2D pyramid and customize border properties
description: By default, a pyramid chart renders as a 3D chart with a context menu, which you can use to switch between 2D and 3D display modes. However, you can configure a pyramid chart to render in the 2D mode when it first loads, without using the context menu. You can also customize the border properties of a pyramid chart for better visual representation.

title: Show labels at the center of the chart
description: Set the value of the showLabelsAtCenter attribute to '1', to show the labels at the center of the chart.

title: Show labels in the legend of the chart
description: You can show the labels in the legend box, instead of showing them with the data plots. To do this, show the legend box and hide the labels for the data plots. The following attributes are used:

title: Configure the position of the legend box
description: By default, the legend box is placed at the bottom of the pyramid chart. You can, however, shift its position to the right. To do that, set the value of the legendPosition attribute to RIGHT.

title: Show data values as percentage
description: You can configure a pyramid chart to show percent values instead of numerical values. To do so, set the value of the showPercentValues attribute to 1.

title: Slice Out Individual Pyramid Slices
description: You can make either all slices, or individual slice(s) of the pyramid chart, appear sliced out. To do so, set the value of the isSliced attribute to 1. Use it as part of the chart object to make the entire chart appear sliced out, or use it as part of the data object, to make one or more segments appear sliced out.

title: Introduction to Bullet Graph
description: A bullet graph is a variation of a bar graph and serves as a light weight replacement for dashboard gauges and meters.

title: Basics of bullet graphs
description: The bullet graph features a single, primary measure (for example, current year-to-date revenue) and compares that measure to one or more other measures to enrich its meaning (for example, compared to a target). It then displays the context of qualitative ranges of performance, such as poor, satisfactory, and good.

title: Types of bullet graphs
description: You can orient bullet graphs horizontally or vertically. You can even stack multiple graphs to compare several measures at once.

title: Features of bullet graphs
description: In bullet graphs, you can:

title: Create bullet graphs
description: As an example, create a bullet graph to show a month's revenue for an organization, where the actual revenue is plotted against the target revenue.

title: Customize color properties

description: To customize the border, use the following attributes:

title: Customize the plot and target width/height
description: By default, the chart automatically decides the width/height (width in case of a vertical bullet graph and height in case of the horizontal bullet graph) based on the data you provide. However, you can configure these manually. Use the following attributes to do so.

title: Configure color
description: You can configure the color range to be filled with a gradient mix instead of a solid color. Use the following attributes to do so.

title: Configure shadow
description: Set the value of showShadow attribute to 1, to enable shadow effects for the color range.

title: Customize tick/value visibility and position
description: In a horizontal bullet graph, tick marks are rendered below the graph by default. However, you can render them above the graph. In a vertical bullet graph, tick marks are rendered on the right, by default. However, you can show them on the left instead. You can also the tick marks and the tick values if you wish. Use the following attributes to do so:

title: Customize the number and cosmetics of major and minor tick marks
description: By default, the chart determines the number of major and minor tick marks automatically, based on the data you provide. However, you can customize them using the attributes given below:

title: Render a dot as the plot instead of a filled bar
description: Set the value of the plotAsDot attribute to 1, to render a dot as the plot.

title: Show/hide chart value
description: Set the value of the showValueattribute to 0, to hide the value.

title: Configure hover effects
description: Use the following attributes to enable and configure hover effects, to improve the visual representation of your gauge.

title: Real-time Bullet Graph
description: The bullet graph (horizontal and vertical bullet) is a real-time chart, which can continuously request new data from the server and display it, without involving any page refresh. The chart initializes itself, loads new data periodically, and auto-updates to reflect the current state of data. There are two different ways to update the bullet graph - one method directly polls data from the server while the other retrieves data using JavaScript API methods.

title: Configure real-time updates using server-side scripts
description: Configure real-time updates from the server using the attributes given below:

description: FusionCharts Suite XT introduces two events to track real-time updates on bullets, realTimeUpdateComplete and realTimeUpdateError.

title: Multi-axis Line Chart
description: A multi-axis line chart, as the name suggests, is an interactive line chart that can be configured for multiple axes.

title: Features
description: The FusionCharts Suite XT multi-axis line chart includes the following features:

title: Create a Multi-Axis Line Chart
description: Let's create our first multi-axis line which will showcase the revenue analysis Harry's SuperMart depending on the revenue, orders, and footfall for 12 weeks.

title: Multi-level Pie Chart
description: The multi-level pie chart is a special type of chart that allows you to show symmetrical/asymmetrical tree structures in a consolidated pie-like structure

title: Configure highlight effect
description: Set the direction of the highlight effect of the plots, when hovered over, using the highlightParentPieSlices and highlightChildPieSlices attributes. For instance:

title: Configure inner radius
description: Use the InnerRadius attribute to explicitly set the inner radius of the pie chart to a value of your choosing.

title: Export Multi-level pie chart in CSV or XLS formats
description: In version 3.13.0, you can export data from multi-level pie charts in CSV or XLS formats. Set the value of the enableExport attribute to 1 to do so.

title: Candlestick Chart
description: The FusionCharts Suite XT candlestick chart offers you a powerful and interactive interface to plot your stock data.

title: Create a Candlestick Chart
description: As an example, we will create a candlestick chart that shows the daily stock price for Harry's SuperMart (stock name HRYS) for the last two months.

title: Set a chart type for the Price chart
description: You can render the price chart using a candle chart, a bar chart, or a line chart. To render the price chart as per your requirement, set plotPriceAs attribute as candlestick, bar or line.

title: Set the Price to Plot for the Line Price chart
description: For a price chart rendered as a line chart, you can decide whether you want to plot the chart w.r.t. the opening price or the closing price, using the plotClosingPrice attribute.

title: Show/Hide the Volume chart
description: The volume chart in a candlestick chart can be set as hidden by specifying the showVolumeChart attribute as 0. The default value for this attribute is 1.

title: Configure Trend-Sets and Trend-Lines
description: Trend-Sets

title: Waterfall Chart
description: A waterfall chart, a type of column chart, used to show how an initial value is increased/decreased by a series of intermediate values, to a final value

title: Customize Colors for the Columns
description: By default, every data plot in a waterfall chart is rendered using a different color irrespective of whether it is a positive or a negative column. You can, however, customize the chart to show distinct colors for the positive and negative columns.

title: Show/Hide Sum Columns
description: Show/Hide a Cumulative Sum Column

title: Customize Connectors
description: Waterfall charts, by default, display connector lines between two consecutive columns which helps in indicating the nature of transition (positive or negative). You can customize the cosmetic properties of these connector lines.

title: Box and Whisker Chart
description: In this section, you will be introduced to the basics of a box and whisker chart, features of a box and whisker chart and five-number summary principle for plotting data on the box and whisker chart.

title: Features
description: The distinct features of a box and whisker chart include:

title: Five-Number Summary Principle
description: The five-number summary principle is used to plot data on the box and whisker charts. This principle helps to provide a statistical summary for a given set of numbers. It gives information about the range (minimum and maximum numbers), the center (median), and the spread (upper and lower quartiles) for the set of values provided. A simple illustration of a box and whisker plot is given below:

title: Create a chart
description: As an example, let's create a box and whisker chart that shows the gender-wise distribution of annual salaries. In the chart, note that the minimum and maximum values and the median will be displayed by default, whereas the upper and lower quartile values will be hidden.

title: Add Legends to the chart
description: FusionCharts Suite XT supports legend for the box and whisker chart. Legend allows you to display single color icons for numeric numbers.

title: Configure the Five Summary Numbers
description: Let's customize the five summary numbers and their deviations plotted on a box and a whisker chart.

title: Configure Mean
description: Mean is the mathematical average for a set of numbers.

title: Configure Mean Deviation
description: Mean deviation is the average of distances between each of the values and the mean. It gives us an idea of how spread out is the set of values from the center.

title: Configure Standard Deviation
description: Standard deviation is the measure of the variation or the dispersion of a set of data from the mean. It gives an idea of how spread out is the set of data from the mean.

title: Configuring Quartile Deviation
description: The distance between the upper quartile and the lower quartile is called the interquartile range. Quartile deviation is half the distance between the two quartiles, i.e., half the interquartile range. It is also called the semi-interquartile range.

title: Configuring Outliers
description: Outliers are values that are numerically distant from the set of numbers provided. They are indicative values which may occur by chance or by error for any set of data provided. Outliers are not included in the statistical calculation of the five summary numbers - the minimum and maximum values, the median value, and the lower and upper quartile values. Instead, they are placed as separate points on the chart.

title: Error Charts
description: An error chart is used to show the extent of uncertainty in information relative to an average value.

title: Use of Error Charts
description: Following are a few areas where error charts are commonly used:

title: Types of Error Charts
description: At present, there are three types of multi-series error charts available in the FusionCharts XT Suite:

title: Features of Error Charts
description: The distinct features of error charts include:

title: Error Bar Chart
description: An error bar chart is a type of an error chart used to show variations in data from its original value. As an example, we will create an error bar chart that compares the lifespan of systems at the Daly City Serramonte, Bakersfield Central, Garden Groove Harbour stores.

title: Error Line Chart
description: Now, let's create an error line chart that compares the estimated procurement from two suppliers. To render an error line chart, change the value of the type attribute from errorbar2d to errorline. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Error Scatter Chart
description: An error scatter chart is an XY plot chart with vertical and horizontal error bars to show a range of error values for a specific data value. As an example, we will create a simple error scatter chart that shows the revenue forecast for the next year.

title: Customize Error Charts
description: You can customize the cosmetic properties of error bars to change their appearance. To customize the properties, follow the steps given below:

title: Spline Charts
description: Spline charts are a specialized form of line charts that display smooth curves through the different data points.

title: Single-Series Spline 2D Chart
description: A single-series spline 2D chart draws a single fitted curve through the data points.

title: Multi-Series Spline Chart
description: To render a multi-series spline chart:

title: Multi-Series Spline Area 2D
description: A multi-series spline area 2D chart is nothing but a conventional area with a smoothed curve drawn through the data points in the series. It allows you to plot data for multiple data sets.

title: Single-Series Spline Area 2D Chart
description: To render a single-series spline area chart, set the type attribute to splinearea.

title: Inverse Y-axis Chart
description: In inverse y-axis charts, y-axis in inverse, the lower limit and upper limit value positions are swapped in an inverse y-axis chart

title: Inverse Y-axis Column Chart
description: Let's create an inverse y-axis chart showcasing Average page load time of hsm.com. In the sample you will observe that when you render the chart, the lower limit value is rendered at the top and the upper limit value is rendered at the bottom - which renders the inverse data plots.

title: Inverse Y-axis Area Chart
description: You have seen how an inverse y-axis column chart looks. To render an inverse y-axis area chart, change the value of the type attribute from inverseMSColumn2D to inverseMSArea. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Inverse Y-axis Line Chart
description: To render an inverse y-axis area chart, change the value of the type attribute from inverseMSArea to inverseMSLine. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Logarithmic Chart
description: Logarithmic charts are similar to normal charts except for the fact that logarithmic charts use a logarithmic axis instead of a linear axis.

title: Types
description: FusionCharts Suite XT offers three types of logarithmic charts:

title: Features
description: The FusionCharts Suite XT log charts offer the following features:

title: Log Column 2D Chart
description: As an example, we will create a log column 2D chart that compares the store footfalls with the online visits for one year.

title: Log Line 2D Chart
description: Now, let's create a log line 2D chart that compares the store footfalls with the online visits for one year. To render a log line 2D chart, change the value of the type attribute from logmscolumn2d to logmsline. The rest of the data structure remains the same.

title: Custom Selection of Base
description: By default, the base of a logarithmic chart is set to 10. You can, however, set the base to any value of your requirement. Just ensure that the base value is any positive number greater than 1. Set the base attribute to specify the base value for the logarithmic chart.

title: Inverse Axis Support
description: Logarithmic charts allow you to plot the y-axis values inversely so that the y-axis upper limit appears at the bottom of the chart canvas instead of at the top. Set the invertYAxis attribute as 1 to specify the inverted y-axis for the chart.

title: Custom Selection of Minor Divisional Lines
description: By default, the chart automatically calculates the number of minor divisional lines depending on the logarithmic base defined in the chart.

title: Step Line Chart
description: It is a specialized line chart which, unlike the usual line charts, does not use the shortest distance to connect two data points

title: Hide the Vertical Lines
description: By default, the step line chart displays the vertical joins - vertical lines that run through the edges of the horizontal planes thereby joining them in different steps. However, you can also disjoin the horizontal segments by hiding the vertical lines from the chart.

title: Use Forward Steps
description: For a step line chart, you can configure the direction of progression of the line segments. By default, the chart is rendered in the forward progressive mode - the line plots are horizontally depicted, and then vertical lines are drawn to connect the data plots. To disable the forward progressive mode, set the useForwardSteps attribute to 0.

title: Kagi Chart
description: Kagi chart uses a series of vertical lines to illustrate general levels of supply and demand for certain assets. These charts are independent of time

title: Drag Node Chart
description: The drag node chart is a spescialized type of chart where each data set is shown on the chart as a drag-able node. Perfect for network diagrams, hierarchy structures, etc., this chart provides a highly intuitive interface for end users to visually adjust related entities, link them, and even add new ones.

title: Configure Drag-node Charts
description: Using FusionCharts Suite XT, you can configure the functional aspects of drag-node charts.

title: Add and edit nodes
description: Using FusionCharts Suite XT, you can customize a drag-node chart in runtime. You can add, edit, or delete nodes in a drag-node chart. To enable this feature, render the chart in edit mode.

title: Customize chart by trapping raised event
description: When you create a new node, a JavaScript event, named nodeAdded, is raised. You can trap and use this event to customize the output, according to your requirements.

description: You can edit all of the properties of a node, except for the ID and the dataset to which it belongs. To edit a node:

description: To delete a node:

title: Add and edit connectors
description: Using FusionCharts Suite XT, you can customize a drag-node chart in runtime. You can add, edit, or delete connectors in a drag-node chart. Set the chart to edit mode to use this feature (enable edit mode by setting "viewMode: 0" in the chart object).

title: Add and Delete Text Labels
description: FusionCharts Suite XT allows you to create individual floating text labels on the chart. This helps in defining a strict text content that can be shown and dragged anywhere on the chart. As of now, you can only add or delete a label, but you cannot edit a label.

title: Update Chart Data on Server
description: In the drag-node chart, you can update data in real-time and submit the modified data to your scripts for further processing.

title: Get data using JavaScript
description: In a drag-node chart, you can update data in real-time. To access the updated JSON data at the client-side using JavaScript, you can parse this data and update your data sources through AJAX, etc.

title: Real-time Charts
description: Real-time charts, also known as data streaming charts, are charts that automatically update themselves after every n seconds, without any page refreshes

title: Add Historical Data
description: In most applications of real-time charts, you would want the chart to initially show historical data and then continue updating itself - instead of starting with a blank canvas and receiving data updates thereafter. You can do this by specifying the historical data in your JSON/XML data.

title: Set Alert Manager
description: The alert manager helps you define thresholds for data values and perform specific actions for the defined thresholds. For example, if you are plotting a real-time temperature chart and wish to play a sound when the temperature reaches between 90 and 100 Fahrenheit, you can do this using the alert manager.

title: Clear Chart View
description: Chart clearing helps to reduce CPU usage by real-time charts when they have been running live for several days or months. Clearing the chart re-instantiates many objects in the chart, thereby clearing a lot of memory.

title: Clear the chart from the Server
description: Consider the following scenario: You are plotting the values of a certain counter, in real-time, 24/7. At the start of each day, you want to clear the existing data being shown on the chart (of the previous day).

description: Real-time charts allow to set a predefined interval in the JSON/XML data to clear the chart. The interval should be specified in clearChartInterval attribute. For the sample given below, we'll set the interval to 50 seconds. Therefore, after every 50 seconds, the chart will clear itself and start drawing with a fresh canvas.

title: Retrieve Data using JavaScript
description: Real-time charts allow you to get the current view of data (i.e., the data which is currently being shown on the chart) using JavaScript.

title: Listen to Events
description: The FusionCharts JavaScript Class API provides some events for real-time charts. These events are categorized into two broad groups - simple events and advanced events. Each event provides arguments to the event-listeners.

title: Event parameters in the simple model
description: In the simple events model, most events (except the FC_Exported and the FC_Resized events) provide the DOM Id of the source chart - the chart that raised the event.

title: Event parameters in the advanced model
description: In the advanced model, two event parameters are passed to the event listener function. The first parameter, eventObject is is structurally common for all events. The second parameter, argumentsObject contains event specific properties.

description: You can manually configure the gauge origins if the automatic adjustment of the origins based on the start and end angle measures does not meet your requirement. To manually set gauge origins, you will need to explicitly set your required values for the gaugeOriginX and gaugeOriginY attributes.

title: Dynamically resize gauges with manual values for elements
description: You can configure the various functional and cosmetic properties of gauge elements by manually specifying values for each, in order to dynamically resize them. For example, you can configure the gauge radius, the dial radius, the tick value distance, the gauge origin, etc. Ideally, you should set these values based on specific width and height dimensions for the gauge. You can name these dimensions as the original width and the original height of the gauge.

title: Set Alert Manager
description: Gauges can be set to update in real time, either programmatically or by polling the server for data. To know more about how to configure a real-time gauge, click here.

title: Use JS API function resizeTo() to resize charts
description: Using the FusionCharts JavaScript API, you can resize an existing chart using the resizeTo() function. You can pass the new width and height of the chart in pixels or percent parameters to the function, or change the width and height property of the chart object and then call the function. The API Method signature for the function is - resizeTo(width:String, height:String).

However, in order to do so, you need to convert any normal gauge to an editable one.

description: The angular gauge is a real time chart, which can continuously request new data from the server and display the same, without involving any page refreshes. The chart initializes itself, loads new data periodically and auto-updates to reflect the current state of data. There are two different ways in which you can update the angular gauge. One way directly polls data from the server, while the other retrieves data using JavaScript API methods.

title: Stream data
description: When you use the real time data format, you need to create a data provider (primarily a server side script) at your server. Next, need to specify the URL of this data provider and the time interval (in seconds), after which the gauge will look for new data. The data provider must then output the new data in the real time data format.

title: Value textbox

description: By default, the gauge automatically determines its origin and radius based on the data you provide. However, FusionCharts Suite XT also allows you to explicitly specify the origin and radius of the gauge.

The chart initializes itself, loads new data periodically, and auto-updates to reflect the current state of data. There are two different ways to update the bulb gauge; one method directly polls data from the server while the other retrieves data using JavaScript API methods.

title: Troubleshoot real-time gauges
description: While accessing any of the JavaScript methods listed above, if you get an error like "... is not a function of ...", make sure that you are NOT running the chart from the local file system (C:\ , D:). Instead, run the chart from behind a server (localhost - IIS, Apache etc.). This is because the default security settings do not allow the chart to perform JavaScript interactions on the local file system.

title: LED Gauge
description: An LED gauge has a horizontal/vertical scale. It uses bars that change color. This section talks about basics of LED gauges along with their useful elements

title: Basics of LED gauges
description: The LED gauge (horizontal/vertical) is defined by its minimum and maximum values. Within that scale, you can create various ranges to classify your data. For example, you might define a range called "Best" that consists of values between 60 and 100. You might also define a range called "Weak" that consists of values between 30 and 60. For each range, you define a color, which helps in visually distinguishing the ranges from each other.

title: Elements of LED gauges
description: In the image below, you can see the basic elements of an LED gauge.

title: Color range
description: You can create various ranges within the minimum and maximum values of an LED gauge. You can create as many ranges as you need. For each range, you need to specify the minimum and maximum limits, a name (rendered as the label for the range), and the hex code for the color of the range.

title: LED bars and gaps
description: The LED bars are the actual data indicators in an LED gauge. The LED bars fill up the container in a ratio that suggests the chart value.

title: Tick marks
description: Tick marks are the calibration marks on the horizontal (or vertical, for the vertical LED) scale to help interpret the reading. There are two types of tick marks which you can draw on the chart:

title: Chart value
description: The chart value indicates the value of the gauge in numeric terms.

title: Annotations
description: Annotations let you draw your own custom shapes, text, or load images on the chart.

description: To create an LED gauge use the attributes given below:

title: Specify the background color
description: Use the gaugeFillColor attribute to specify the hex code of the color to be applied to the gauge background.

title: Use a single color for LED fill and background
description: When you divide the LED scale into color ranges, the LED bars in each zone take up the fill color of that color range. You can, however, render the LED background using a single fill color (the color of the range to which the current value belongs).

title: Show/Hide the gauge border
description: Set the value of the showGaugeBorder attribute to specify whether the border for the LED gauge should be displayed

description: Use the following attributes to customize the gauge border:

description: By default, the gauge determines the bar size and the gap automatically, based on the data provided by you. However, you can explicitly specify the bar size and gap. Use the following attributes to do so:

title: Show/hide chart value
description: Set the value of the showValue attribute to 1, to specify whether the current data value, or the chart value, should be displayed.

title: Show/hide tick marks and tick values
description: Use the following attributes to show/hide tick marks and tick values:

title: Configure tick marks and tick values
description: By default, the tick marks and values are placed below the gauge in the horizontal LED gauge and to the right in the vertical LED gauge. However, you can explicitly configure the position of tick marks and tick values as required. Use the following attributes to configure tick marks and tick values:

title: Configure tick mark and tick value cosmetics
description: You can also use FusionCharts Suite XT to configure the cosmetics of major and minor tick marks. Use the following attributes to do so:

title: Configure hover effects
description: Using FusionCharts Suite XT, you can display hover effects for the gauge. Set the value of the showHoverEffect attribute to 1, to enable hover effects for an LED gauge.

title: Real time LED gauge
description: The LED gauge is a real time chart, which can continuously request new data from the server and display the same, without involving any page refreshes. The chart initializes itself, loads new data every n seconds, and silently updates itself to reflect the current state of data. There are two different ways you can update the LED gauge; one method directly polls data from the server while the other retrieves data using JavaScript API methods.

description: FusionCharts Suite XT introduces two events, realTimeUpdateComplete and realTimeUpdateError, to track real time updates on gauges.

title: Troubleshoot real time gauges
description: While accessing any of the JavaScript methods listed above, if you get an error like "... is not a function of ...", make sure that you are NOT running the chart from the local file system (C:\ , D:). Instead, run the chart from behind a server (localhost - IIS, Apache, etc.). This is because the default security settings do not allow the chart to perform JavaScript interaction on the local file system, unless otherwise specifically set.

title: Configure tick values
description: When you have a large number of tick marks on the gauge scale, showing all tick values can make the gauge appear cluttered. To avoid this, you can show every nth tick value on the gauge scale. You can also configure whether decimal values are to be rendered as tick values and the number of digits that should appear after the decimal point.

title: Configure positions of tick marks and tick values
description: By default, the tick marks are placed outside the gauge, below the gauge scale. The tick values are also rendered outside the gauge. You can, however, configure the position of tick marks and tick values based on your requirements.

title: Configure the number of major and minor tick marks
description: By default, the gauge automatically decides the number of major and minor tick marks to be rendered, based on the data you provide. However, you can explicitly specify the number of tick marks to be rendered.
